acadian_redfish.habitat: Deep waters over rocky, mud, or clay ocean bottoms
acadian_redfish.distribution: Northwest Atlantic, from Iceland to the Gulf of Maine

adriatic_sturgeon.habitat: Freshwater rivers and coastal marine waters
adriatic_sturgeon.distribution: Endemic to the Adriatic Sea and its tributaries

african_coelacanth.habitat: Deep marine waters, typically in caves and steep slopes
african_coelacanth.distribution: Western Indian Ocean, near the Comoros and Madagascar

alabama_shad.habitat: Freshwater rivers and coastal marine waters
alabama_shad.distribution: Southeastern United States, Gulf of Mexico drainages

alaska_pollock.distribution: North Pacific Ocean, especially the Bering Sea

almaco_jack.habitat: Deep oceanic waters near reefs and wrecks
almaco_jack.distribution: Worldwide in tropical and subtropical oceans
almaco_jack.weight: Typically 10-20 pounds (4.5-9 kg), can exceed 50 pounds (22.7 kg)

american_plaice.distribution: Northwest Atlantic, from Greenland to Rhode Island

argentine_angelshark.habitat: Sandy or muddy bottoms of continental shelves
argentine_angelshark.distribution: Southwest Atlantic, off the coasts of Argentina and Uruguay

arrowtooth_flounder.distribution: North Pacific Ocean, from California to Alaska

atlantic_bigeye_tuna.habitat: Open ocean, epipelagic to mesopelagic zones
atlantic_bigeye_tuna.distribution: Tropical and subtropical waters of the Atlantic Ocean

atlantic_blacktip_shark.distribution: Worldwide in tropical and subtropical waters

basking_shark.habitat: Temperate coastal waters and open oceans, often near the surface.
basking_shark.distribution: Widely distributed in temperate oceans, including the North Atlantic, North Pacific, and Mediterranean Sea.
basking_shark.number_of_species: 1 (It is the only species in the genus Cetorhinus).
basking_shark.conservation_status: Endangered (due to overfishing and habitat disturbance).
basking_shark.diet: Plankton, small fish, and invertebrates. It is a filter feeder.
basking_shark.size: Average length of 6–8 meters, but can grow up to 12 meters.

hammerhead_shark.habitat: Coastal warm waters, continental shelves, and deep oceanic waters.
hammerhead_shark.distribution: Worldwide in tropical and temperate oceans, including the Atlantic, Pacific, and Indian Oceans.
hammerhead_shark.number_of_species: 9 (including the Great Hammerhead, Scalloped Hammerhead, and Smooth Hammerhead).
hammerhead_shark.conservation_status: Critically Endangered to Vulnerable (varies by species, mainly due to overfishing and finning).
hammerhead_shark.diet: Fish, squid, octopuses, and crustaceans. Some species also eat other sharks and rays.
hammerhead_shark.size: Ranges from 0.9 to 6 meters depending on the species. The Great Hammerhead can reach up to 6 meters.
hammerhead_shark.weight: From 3 kg to over 450 kg depending on the species.

octopus.habitat: Marine environments, from shallow coastal waters to deep ocean floors
octopus.distribution: Worldwide in oceans, from tropical reefs to polar regions
octopus.conservation_status: Varies by species; some are not threatened, while others may be at risk
octopus.diet: Crustaceans, mollusks, fish, and other small marine animals
octopus.size: Arm spans range from a few centimeters to over 30 feet (9 meters) in the giant Pacific octopus
octopus.weight: From less than an ounce to over 150 pounds (70 kg)
octopus.lifespan: Typically 1-2 years; larger species may live up to 5 years

tiger_shark.habitat: Coastal and open ocean waters, often near coral reefs and estuaries
tiger_shark.diet: Fish, seals, birds, squid, turtles, sea snakes, and even inedible objects
tiger_shark.size: Commonly 10-14 feet (3-4.3 meters); can reach up to 18 feet (5.5 meters)

whale_shark.habitat: Warm, tropical ocean waters; often found in open seas and near coastal areas
whale_shark.distribution: Worldwide in tropical and warm temperate seas
